label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, December 17, 1942
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding a visit to family in their home, Andalusia, a dinner party she had hosted, Christmas gifts, and Medway Plantation.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding a visit to family in their home, Andalusia, a dinner party she had hosted, Christmas gifts, and Medway Plantation.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Do your orders emulate from Sincpack or Carminch?
43 recvd 12 28 42 Dec 17th
Dear Doodle-ears,
I got back from Andalusia this morning. Olive and I decided to
we should go and see Kathrine together and spend a day with her - so I told my office
I wanted the day off and took it. We went up on a nine A.M. train on the coldest
day I have ever felt.I think it was 18[percent] we changed and wairted an hour at North
Philla and than Kathrine met us at Andalusia. Both Olive and Kathrine had such
colds they could hardly speak. This ofcourse made no difference to Kathrine
who put on her woolen underwear and took me for an hour's walk over snow and
ice around the roads we all bycicled over together last summer. Olive stayed
by the fire. We spent most of the day conversing. It was great fun.Kathrine
I really adore and we had a "talk Fest". She had gone to NJ. to see Morris'
offspring,and found Nancy looking in the pink on a very fine corner room on
the River. She had been to Fort Bragg to see Henry and hopes Henry will get
has leave. Little Charlie a senior at St Pauls is studdying to be an air
pilot when called. Little Bobbie Phillips has joined the Marines but will
stay at Colledge till called. Big Charlie came back for dinner and we re-
viewed the entire Legendre situation with him. All the details about Armant[,]
and read them your funny letter about you and Morris in the car witha bottle
[o]f champaine out in the flood when the river bubbled around you. We had great
fun. I took the ten o'clock train home and took the sleeper from Broad St.
which got me in at 7 A.M. Everyone is snuffling anfgurggling and you have never
seen such colds in your life. I have not yet had a scorcher. That no doubt lies
in wait for me later on.
I had the great Ace for dinner Col. Carmaichel, his wife,
Char[l]ie Baskerville and Moorhead.I think I told you something about this in
my last letter. Olive ate it up. The Flyer was the top. Only 29 and a Clolonel
-just as modest and sweet as he could be. He let me in on the "Short Snorters["]
Club" because I had flown the ocean,so we all exchnaged dollare bills with
our respective signatures. Do you know about the"Short Sorters?" ? I guess so.
He and his wife must have had fun because they never went home till nearly
one A.M. I could n't believe it. He was so cute about his delight at being
once more in a private house,and said it was the best evening he had had
since he has been back. He gets 15 days[,]then a new assignement. He told me
he was pleased and enthused at what the Air effort here consisted of. He thought
it was tops and had only the highest praise for Arnold. I liked him.
I am going to have dinner on a tray to-night,and then to-morrow
Idine with David Bruce at the Aliby Club. Xmas is getting awfully close and
[I] have not done half my shopping.
I sent you an other little picture frame to-day air-mail with
two photos which I hope you will like. Ofcourse I dont expect this to reach
you before Xmas possibly. I do hope my mail has started to arrive again and
that you are getting letters.
My fingers are crossed for you to stay in Hawaii and I wish
the same wish every day. If wishewere helpful- you have mine,and you should
stay there without a counter order,.Iam always so frightened I shall here you
are off. How I hope if you do go anywhere I do hope you go to-gether. It
would be so perfect for you.
[End Page 1]
2
When you are two you can take care of each other and I like to think of you two
always staying together and taking care of eachother. Incidently [I] dont guess its
really care you give each other -it seems to me you are trying to poison eachother
with those concoctions you whip up. How does the old indegestion stand it? I would
really like to know. When I think of the time spent at Mr.Martins' Mrs Bett's, Dr
Green etc and how we babied the old tumtum along with milk and home cooking- ye
Gods it makes me wince to think of the canned goods that float or sink inside your
innards,and the pies, cakes and goodies mixed and brewed by Chef Morris that explode
like bombs below your deck[or rather girth[] How is the old body bearing up? Will
you be wanting only milktoast and soft foods when you get back or will you be ready
for hardtack -pork and beans[?] I long to know. Where do you keep the Bicarb? Is it
right beside the Rhum on the Kitchen shelf? I hope so. I would love to have a
phonagraph record of some of those kitchen capers you two ahrangue over as I bet
it would make me laugh.
Honey is back ehre with me as Landine moved to Middleburg to
finish up her school as Foxcroft closed earlier. Honey is very sweet and he now
get a great deal of petting. My pupy Jeep is still with Mrs Cornell being trained
for these pearly grey rugs.
Lizzie has now also returned to the Plantation as Johnie her
husband wanted her to and made such a row she had to go. We are left once more
completely alone with Rose to cook for us all over the Xmas hollidays. Hi ho what
a life. Its fine for me as Rose is a swell cook but whether she can hold out is
an other pr[o]blem. She really should have a holliday with Sherin over Xmas but I see
no chance of it. She made an other trip to N.Y.C. to canvas the Agencyes but has
no luck at all. No one will come to Washington at any price- nohow.
North Afica seems to be going fine, and I wonder where Janie is
in the midst of all those air raids. Probably entertaining Fifi andBaba and Tulio
and all the other people that sounded like that to me. She probably finds it "very
interesting" although a little hard to get caviar. I wonder.
I am having a little tiny table tree this year as I have no Xmas
deccorations but it will look gay and then I have bought the children stockings
and am giving Landine a leather writing case from you and Bo a trycycle form Daddy.
I shall miss you so my Darling I try not to think about it. Do you remmeber last
Xmas what fun we had at Medway. Bo was wide eyed surrounded by red and white tissue
paper. Xmas never means much in the tropics anyhow but I do hope you get your parcels
and I do hope that by now Wing Pepper has brought you those foolish little goodluck
pieces that I send you with all my love. The fourleaf clover is to put on that key
ring I gave you[if you still have it] It will bring you luck.I know it will.
There is not point sending you big things.You never will be able to pack them- so
I sent you food, nonsence, books and magazenes.
I shall telephone you son.
Loads of love to you both,but the mostest to you my darling whom
I hug and kiss over and over again.
Gertie
[illegible]
[End Page 2]
